p.span:
The SPEAKER ( Hon.
Milton Dick ) took the chair at 10:00, made an acknowledgement of country and read prayers.
COMMITTEES
Petitions Committee
Report

Ms TEMPLEMAN
( Macquarie ) ( 10:01 ):
I present the 35th report of the Petitions Committee for the 47th Parliament.
Chair Ms Susan Templeman MP
Deputy Chair Mr Ross Vasta MP
Mr Sam Birrell MP
Ms Alison Byrnes MP
Ms Lisa Chesters MP
Mr Garth Hamilton MP
Ms Tracey Roberts MP
Ms Meryl Swanson MP
This committee is supported by staff of the Department of the House of Representatives

span.span: Report summarising the petitions and ministerial responses being presented.
The committee met in private session in the 47th Parliament on 20 November 2024.
1. The committee resolved to present the following 3 petitions in accordance with standing order 207:

p.span: From 6 petitioners—requesting that the Australian Government address the persecution of Falun Gong practitioners (PN0620)
From 111 petitioners—requesting a mandate that all chocolate sold in Australia is produced without the use of child labour (PN0626)
From 2523 petitioners—requesting stronger targets for reducing greenhouse gas emissions and achieving net-zero emissions (PN0628)

span.span: 2. The following 17 ministerial responses to petitions were received.
Ministerial responses received by the Committee on 20 November 2024

p.span: From the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs to a petition requesting the reinstatement of expired Skilled-Recognised Graduate (subclass 476) visas for people impacted by travel restrictions (EN3685)
From the Assistant Treasurer to a petition requesting improvements to the myGovID program (EN4607)
From the Treasurer to a petition regarding the Reserve Bank of Australia (EN4978)
From the Minister for Housing to a petition requesting a nationwide cap on rental price increases (EN6068)
From the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry to a petition requesting that the live animal export industry be maintained (EN6241)
From the Minister for Foreign Affairs to a petition requesting that people who have served in the Israel Defense Forces be prohibited from returning to Australia (EN6295)
From the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs to a petition requesting support to recruit qualified pharmacists from overseas (EN6312)
From the Minister for Communications to a petition requesting that independent local post offices be able to provide additional services to support communities (EN6326 and PN0615)

From the Attorney-General to a petition requesting that consumers be given the right to opt-out of their personal data being collected and used to train artificial intelligence by social media platforms (EN6356)

From the Assistant Minister for Social Services to a petition requesting that the Australian Government support the implementation of the domestic violence disclosure scheme known as Clare's Law (EN6437)

From the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs to a petition requesting a pathway to permanent residency for people who lived and worked in Australia during the COVID-19 pandemic (EN6443)
From the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs to a petition requesting support for Hong Kong civilians to gain protection in Australia (EN6475)
From the Minister for Health and Aged Care to a petition requesting that hypnotherapy treatments be included in the Medicare Benefits Schedule (EN6485)
From the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs to a petition requesting that immigration be reduced (EN6494)
From the Assistant Minister for Social Services to a petition regarding the National Redress Scheme for Institutional Child Sexual Abuse (EN6498)
From the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs to a petition requesting a pathway to permanent residency for people who engaged in farmwork during the COVID-19 pandemic (EN6544)
From the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs to a petition regarding the resettlement of refugees from Indonesia (PN0613)
PETITIONS
Presentation

Ms TEMPLEMAN
( Macquarie ) ( 10:01 ):
I present the following three petitions:
Falun Gong

Falun Gong (also known as Falun Dafa) is a spiritual practice in the Buddhist tradition centred on the principles of truthfulness, compassion, and forbearance. The practice aims to improve physical, mental, and spiritual well-being through meditation and moral improvement. In 1999, an estimated 70-100 million followers of Falun Gong in China became the target of suppression when the ruling communist regime saw the popularity of the practice as a threat. For the past 25 years, Falun Gong practitioners have been subjected to the most brutal extermination campaign, with widespread physical, mental, sexual, and psychiatric abuse. In addition, the China Tribunal concluded in 2019 that "forced organ harvesting has been committed for years throughout China on a significant scale and that Falun Gong practitioners have been one—and probably the main- source of organ supply."
We therefore ask the House to

1. Urge the People's Republic of China (PRC) to immediately end the persecution of Falun Gong practitioners and unconditionally release all Falun Gong practitioners and other prisoners of conscience, particularly the family members of Australian citizens and residents;
2. Call on the Australian Government to raise the issue of Falun Gong and the wider religious freedom situation at every dialogue with the PRC and ask the PRC to respect freedom of belief;
3. Call on the Australian Government to implement Magnitsky-style sanctions against individuals and entities participating in the persecution of Falun Gong practitioners.
from six citizens (Petition No. PN0620)
Child Labour

Children in other countries are sometimes forced to work in farms and factories to make chocolate, and are often exposed to chemicals and other harmful substances. Some are even taken away from their families.
We therefore ask the House to ensure that all chocolate sold in Australia is free from child labour.
from 111 citizens (Petition No. PN0626)
Climate Change

According to the Climate Council, Australia's target to reduce greenhouse gas emissions to 43% below 2005 levels by 2030 is insufficient to prevent self-sustaining and irreversible climate change of catastrophic levels. Instead, they present a minimum 75% reduction as imperative. As a country with one of the highest greenhouse gas emission rates per capita, it is Australia's duty to reduce emissions faster in order to protect our own and the world's environments and people.

We therefore ask the House to initiate a legislated pledge to reduce Australia's greenhouse gas emissions to 75% below 2005 levels by 2030, instead of the target for 43%; and to replace the net-zero emissions target of 2050 with a new target of 2040.
from 2,523 citizens (Petition No. PN0628)
Petitions received.
PETITIONS
Responses
Ms TEMPLEMAN (Macquarie) (10:01): I present the following 17 ministerial responses to petitions previously presented:
Migration
Dear Chair

I refer to correspondence of 14 February 2022 to the former Minister for Immigration, Citizenship, Migrant Services and Multicultural Affairs, the Hon Alex Hawke MP, enclosing Petition EN3685, with 640 signatures, concerning the reinstatement of expired Skilled-Recognised Graduate (subclass 476) visas for those impacted by the COVID-19 international travel restrictions. Your correspondence has been referred to me as the matters falls within my portfolio responsibilities.

On the 7 March 2022, the former Government announced several concessions for visa holders impacted by the COVID-19 pandemic travel restrictions. This included current and former subclass 476 visa holders who had lost time in Australia having their visas extended.

On 5 April 2022, almost 3,000 eligible subclass 476 visa holders had their visa extended until 14 April 2024. The Department of Home Affairs directly notified eligible visa holders of the extension of their visa to facilitate their travel. Further details related to this visa concession is available on the Department's Skilled- Recognised Graduate visa website at: https://immi.homeaffairs.gov.au/visas/getting- a-visa/visa-listing/skilled-recognition-graduate-476.

The Migration Strategy released on 11 December 2023 outlined the Australian Government's vision for getting migration working for the nation and building a migration system that delivers for workers, businesses and all Australians. The strategy highlighted that there were multiple and confusing graduate visa products and confirmed that the Skilled-Recognised Graduate visa no longer aligns with policy priorities. The visa was subsequently capped on 22 December 2023, and permanently closed to new applications from 1 July 2024.

Internationally qualified engineers may have alternative pathways to work in Australia. To investigate options, applicants may visit the visa finder at: https://immi.homeaffairs.gov.au/visas/getting-a-visa/visa-finder.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN3685 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Burke
MyGovID
Thank you for your correspondence, originally directed to the Minister for Government Services, the Hon Bill Shorten MP concerning Petition EN4607 on myGovID.

The Government is delivering simple, secure and connected public services for all Australians through world class data and digital capabilities. Central to this are the myGov and myGovID services administered by Services Australia, the Australian Taxation Office and Digital Transformation Agency.

MyGov is a voluntary online digital service that is a simple and secure way for Australians to access and communicate with a range of government services, including the Australian Taxation Office (ATO), in one place. MyGovID is a whole-of-government digital identity (ID) solution which can be used by Australians via the myGovID application to prove who they are online. It allows users to confirm their identity only once, which can then be re-used to access participating government online services, saving users time and removing the inconvenience of having to constantly prove their identity with every interaction.

MyGovID's role is that of an accredited Identity provider (ldP) within the Australian Government's Digital ID System (AGDIS). An IdP's role is to help individuals set up and manage their digital ID so they can prove who they are online. More than 12 million myGovIDs have been created that can be used to access more than 140 government services across Commonwealth, states, and territories.

MyGovID is a voluntary service and does not have any bearing on access or eligibility requirements for applying or receiving Government rebates, entitlements or refunds. Such requirements are established by law and administered in accordance with the law by the relevant government agency. No Australian individual or business is denied access to government assistance or a legal entitlement because they do not have myGov or myGovID. If users are having difficulty creating a myGovID or using the service to access support or information, they can access guidance material and contact details from the myGovID website—mygovid.gov.au.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Financial Services, Mr Jones
Reserve Bank of Australia
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN4978 regarding the Reserve Bank of Australia (RBA).

On 20 April 2023, the Albanese Government released the findings of the first external review of the RBA and the operation of monetary policy since current arrangements were instituted in the early 1990s. The Review found that Australia's monetary policy framework has contributed to good economic outcomes in

Australia over the past three decades but identified opportunities to strengthen it. One recommendation of the Review is to conduct 5-yearly reviews of the RBA's monetary policy framework and tools to ensure the RBA's approach remains appropriate into the future. The Government is working to implement the Review's recommendations. The Government implemented some of the recommendations last year through an updated agreement with the RBA and currently has legislation before Parliament.

We acknowledge that higher interest rates have been very challenging for Australians who are already doing it tough. Households are under pressure from higher costs of living, and higher interest rates have added further pressure.

The Government does not intervene in the decisions taken by the independent RBA, which aims to keep inflation between 2 and 3 per cent a year. The Government agrees with the RBA that inflation remains a key challenge in our economy. The Government's economic plan is focused on fighting inflation in our economy and providing responsible cost of living relief.

The Government's tax cuts for all Australian taxpayers commenced on 1 July 2024. To ease pressure on low- and middle-income Australian households, changes made by the Government are delivering bigger tax cuts for them in a way that does not add to the inflation outlook. The Government also increased the Medicare levy low-income thresholds for singles, families, seniors and pensioners from 1 July 2023.

The Government is also delivering cost-of-living relief to help ease pressure on households and businesses. The 2024-25 Budget delivered further cost-of-living relief, including energy bill relief for all households and eligible small businesses, further increasing Commonwealth Rent Assistance, making medicines cheaper, and reducing student debt.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Treasurer, Mr Chalmers
Housing
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence concerning Petition EN6068 on rental price increases.
The petition asks for the Commonwealth Government to regulate increases in rental prices including limiting the size of an increase in any given time period.

The Government recognises that many renters are under pressure and that rising rents are causing hardship for some Australians. However, under the Constitution state and territory governments are responsible, for the regulation of residential tenancies, including rental agreements, rent controls and pricing.

The Commonwealth Government is working with the states and territories to deliver improved housing outcomes for all Australians, including those that are renting. At National Cabinet in August 2023 states and territories agreed to strengthen renters' rights through the Better Deal for Renters package. As part of this package, all levels of government have agreed to implement a 9-point plan that includes:
Developing a nationally consistent policy to implement a requirement for genuine reasonable grounds for eviction.
Moving towards limiting rent increases to once a year.
Phasing in minimum rental standards.
These changes will make a tangible impact for the almost one-third of Australian households who rent. In the 2024-25 Budget, the Government announced it would increase maximum rates of Commonwealth
Rent Assistance (CRA) by a further 10 per cent to help relieve rental cost pressures for recipient households.

This represents an investment of $1.9 billion over five years from 2023-24, and builds on the Government's 15 per cent increase to CRA maximum rates in the last Budget. These are the first back-to-back increases in rent assistance in over 30 years.
The 10 per cent increase was implemented on 20 September 2024, in addition to regular indexation occurring on top of this on the same day.

The Government does not support rent freezes. There is strong consensus in academic literature on the negative impacts of rent freezes as they reduce both the quantity and quality of housing available in the market, making it harder for tenants to secure housing that meets their needs. The Government's response to the Senate Rental Inquiry on the worsening rental crisis in Australia, tabled on 14 May 2024, emphasises the most effective way to sustainably improve rental affordability is to increase housing supply and refers to the Government's housing agenda to demonstrate work already underway to address concerns raised by the recommendations.
The Government Response to the Senate Rental Inquiry into the worsening rental crisis can be found here www.treasury.gov.au/publication/p2024-530586.
More broadly, we continue to work with state, territory, and local governments to deliver better housing outcomes.
I trust this information will be of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Housing, Ms O'Neil
Live Animals Export
Dear Chair

Thank you for your email dated 1 July 2024, to the former Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, Senator the Hon Murray Watt, concerning petition number EN6241. I apologise for the delay in my response.
The Albanese Labor Government took this policy to the 2019 and 2022 elections, and we are providing certainty, time and support to navigate this important transition.

In July 2024, both houses of the Federal Parliament agreed to ban live sheep exports by sea from 1 May 2028. This brings Australia's laws in line with community expectations in relation to sheep welfare and delivers on our election commitment.

The Parliament passing legislation provides certainty for the live sheep export industry to make decisions for the future by providing a clear end date of 1 May 2028 and it enables the delivery of a transition assistance package.

We understand that this change will have impacts on the sector, and we have committed $139.7 million over five years to assist affected sheep farmers, businesses in the supply chain and communities to plan for and adapt to the phase out.

This includes $97.3 million of funding specifically allocated to assist sheep producers and supply chain businesses to transition away from live sheep exports by sea and take advantage of the rapidly growing demand for sheepmeat, currently valued at around $4.5 billion a year.

The transition assistance package also includes funding of $27 million to increase market demand, explore market development opportunities and advocate for Australian products at home and overseas. This will help to ensure participants in the supply chain are supported to capitalise on emerging opportunities and are well positioned when the trade ends.

For more information on the implementation of the transition assistance package, please visit the Department of Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry's website: www.agriculture.qov.au/live-sheep-phase-out.
Thank you again for bringing petition number EN6241 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Agriculture, Fisheries and Forestry, Ms Collins
Israel
Dear Chair
Thank you for your email of 12 August 2024 regarding petition number EN6295 concerning Australian citizens in the Israeli Defense Force.
The Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade does not track the movements of Australians overseas.

Under the Criminal Code Act 1995 (Criminal Code), it is an offence for Australians to engage in hostile activities overseas, unless serving in or with the armed forces of a foreign country. These laws are designed to prevent Australians from fighting in overseas conflicts and endangering their lives and the lives of others.

The Government encourages all Australians who seek to serve with the armed forces of a foreign country to carefully consider their legal obligations, and ensure their conduct does not constitute a criminal offence.

Allegations of Commonwealth offences should be reported to the Australian Federal Police (AFP). The AFP works closely with foreign law enforcement agencies and international bodies to support investigations into alleged international offences.
Thank you very much for your correspondence on this important matter.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Foreign Affairs, Senator Wong
Skilled Migration
Dear Chair

Thank you for you correspondence of 12 August 2024, enclosing Petition EN6312, with 186 signatures, concerning migration options for pharmacists. I appreciate the time you have taken to bring this matter to my attention.

The Australian Government is committed to supporting Australia's healthcare sector through skilled migration. Healthcare occupations are prioritised in the skilled migration program, which means faster processing of skilled visas for healthcare workers, including pharmacists. Under the 2023-24 permanent Migration Program, 16,572 places were delivered to primary applicants in healthcare occupations, 822 of which were in pharmacy occupations. Most of these places were delivered under state and territory nominated visa categories.

The petition calls for an increase to state and territory visa allocations. State and territory nominated migration programs allow each jurisdiction to nominate visa applicants with skills and occupations that meet their specific labour market needs.

For 2024-25, the Government has increased the planning levels for the State and Territory Nominated category to 33,000 visas and the Regional category (which largely consist of state and territory nominated places) to 33,000 visas. This is an additional 3,300 places for these program. Increasing the planning levels has also allowed the Government to increase, by 57 per cent, the number of prospective applicants that jurisdictions can nominate in these visa programs. This means that there is now greater opportunity for State and Territory Governments to nominate pharmacists for a visa and for these applicants to be granted a visa under the Migration Program.

The Government's Migration Strategy also outlines steps the Government is taking to simplify the migration system for migrants and employers. This includes creating a new Skills in Demand visa with clear pathways to permanent residence and streamlined labour market testing requirements to reduce complexity.

Australian employers, including pharmacies, can find detailed information on how to navigate the process for sponsoring overseas workers on the Department of Home Affairs' website at: https://immi.homeaffairs.gov.au/visas/employing-and-sponsoring- someone/employing-overseas-workers.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN6312 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Burke
Australia Post
Dear Chair

Thank you for your letter of 19 August 2024 regarding petitions EN6326 and PN0615, requesting that restrictions be removed to allow the Licensees of Independent Local Post Offices to provide additional services and choice to better serve local communities and remain sustainable.

Firstly, I would like to acknowledge the dedication and continued service of the more than 3,400 Australia Post Licensees, particularly in supporting Australia Post to deliver recent letter delive1y reforms.

The Australian Government appreciates licensees are the lifeblood of communities and play a crucial role in ensuring ongoing access to postal and other essential services across Australia. The Government remains committed to helping Australia Post adapt to the digitisation of the economy so that it remains a cherished national institution, providing essential services to Australian communities.

This is particularly critical in regional, rural and remote areas of Australia, where Australia Post is a key provider of a wide range of services that support the economic and social wellbeing of communities.

The Government remains focused on priority reforms to realise a more efficient letter service. On 15 April 2024, new Performance Standards for Australia Post took operational effect to enable letter delivery to change from every business day to every second business day for 90 per cent of delive1y points across Australia.

Significant financial and productivity benefits from these reforms are already being realised, including $56 million in cost savings through rollout of a new delive1y model, to be reinvested in electric postie bikes and the expansion of regional parcel facilities.
Additionally, the Government has set clear service expectations in a revised Statement of Expectations for Australia Post in implementing these reforms, including that it:
maintains investment in its delivery and retail networks to meet end user needs including in regional, rural and remote Australia.
continues to offer services where they are commercially viable, with regard to the needs of communities and Australia Post's financial sustainability; and
increases accessibility of out-of-home parcel delivery options through other means such as parcel lockers and other self-service options.

Australia Post is estimated to deliver more than 70 per cent of business to consumer parcels through its national delivery and Post Office network. Australia Post already supports end-to- end access arrangements on a commercial basis with over 80 parcel industry intermediaries and competitors—consistent with that of global postal providers in similar jurisdictions.

Australia Post has advised it is open to considering additional parcel delivery service arrangements provided they are commercially sound, and benefits can be shared by all parties. There are no legislative impediments or Government policies preventing Australia Post striking such arrangements.

Despite challenging headwinds in the retail industry, Australia Post continues to support over 3,500 Licensed Post Offices (LPOs) and Community Postal Agencies through strong parcel growth, and other service offerings like Bank@Post. In 2023-24, commissions associated with articles delivered to customers through LPOs grew 14.1 per cent, and LPO commission payments grew by $16.3 million year-on-year, or 2.9 per cent.

Additionally, Australia Post's Licensed Post Office Agreement allows licensees to sell a range of additional non-Australia Post products. These arrangements underpin the success of the LPO network and contribute to Australia Post's ongoing viability and sustainability.
The Government will continue to work with Australia Post, licensees and communities so that services meet the needs of modern Australia, consistent with existing regulatory requirements.
Thank you for bringing this matter to the Australian Government's attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Communications, Ms Rowland
Artificial Intelligence
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 12 August 2024 to the Hon Michelle Rowland MP, Minister for Communications, concerning Petition EN6356. As the issues raised in this petition fall within my portfolio 1:esponsibilities as the Attorney-General, the petition was referred to me for a response.

The Government acknowledges the concerns around the use of personal information on social media to train AI models. It is vital that Australia's privacy laws properly protect Australians' personal information, and that they keep pace with technological developments and global standards.

The Privacy Act 1988 (Privacy Act) protects the privacy of Australians by regulating the collection, use, disclosure and storage of personal information. It contains the Australian Privacy Principles (APPs) which apply to Australian Government agencies and private sector organisations with an annual turnover of over $3 million. APP 6 provides that where personal information has been collected for a primary purpose, it must not be used for a secondary purpose unless the individual has consented or an exception applies. One of the exceptions is where the individual would 'reasonably expect' the information to be used for the secondary purpose. However, the Office of the Australian Information Commissioner has recently released guidance stating that organisations seeking to rely on this exception should only do so where they can: show that a reasonable person who is properly informed would expect their information to be used in this way.[1]

The Government is committed to strengthening privacy protections to provide Australians with more choice and control over their information. The Attorney-General's Department's comprehensive review of the Privacy Act was released in February 2023. The Government's Response to this review was published in September 2023 and is available online at https://www.ag.gov.au/rights-and-protections/publications/government-response-privacy- act-review-report.

In this response, the Government agreed or agreed in-principle to progress the vast majority of proposals to amend the Privacy Act, including reforms to ensure that consent, where provided, is meaningful and that collection, use and disclose of personal information is 'fair and reasonable' in the circumstances. This proposal would require entities to handle personal information in a way which Australians would reasonably expect, regardless of whether consent had been provided.
1 Guidance on privacy and the use of commercially available AI products I OAIC
This test would set a baseline of protections to give Australians confidence when they engage in the digital economy.

Additional proposals that the Government has agreed or agreed in-principle include requiring entities to be more transparent about how they handle personal information and providing individuals with a right to have their personal information erased.

On 12 September 2024, I introduced the Privacy and Other Legislation Bill 2024 into the Parliament. The Bill would legislate a first tranche of privacy reforms and introduce a new statutory tort for serious invasions of privacy and new offences targeting the release of personal data in a manner that would be menacing or harassing.

The Government will continue to progress the remaining proposals to which we agreed in principle in our Response to the Privacy Act Review. This will involve targeted consultation on draft provisions to inform the Government's decisions on next steps and a future package of reforms.
I trust this information is of assistance.
Yours sincerely
from the Attorney-General, Mr Dreyfus
Domestic and Family Violence
Dear Ms Templeman

Thank you for your email dated 8 October 2024 to the Minister for Social Services, the Hon Amanda Rishworth MP, concerning petition EN6437—Calling for Clare's Law to be implemented nationally. The Minister has asked me to respond on her behalf.
I acknowledge the concerns identified in this petition and thank those who participated for raising this matter with the Australian Government.

Under Australia's federal system of government, the primary responsibility for criminal matters rests with the states and territories, with each jurisdiction managing their own justice systems and law enforcement agencies. As such, the establishment of a Domestic Violence Disclosure Scheme (DVDS) is a matter for the states and territories.

However, the Government is dedicated to strengthening justice responses to keep women and children safe from violence. The National Domestic Violence Order Scheme (NDVOS) has been in place since 2017. It seeks to ensure protections for Domestic Violence Orders (DVOs) are recognised and enforced across Australia. The NDVOS is a model law statutory scheme under which jurisdictions automatically recognise and enforce one another's DVOs. It is currently underpinned by an interim information-sharing solution that leverages the National Police Reference System (managed by the Australian Criminal Intelligence Commission) to provide police and courts with information on DVOs issued across Australia. The NDVOS helps to improve police situational awareness when responding to domestic violence incidents, improving both victim and police safety, and ensures local courts can recognise, amend and otherwise effectively deal with DVO, even if issued interstate.

In addition, the Government has made women's safety a national priority through the development and implementation of the National Plan to End Violence against Women and Children 2022-32 (the National Plan).

The National Plan, its First Action Plan 2023-27 and the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander Action Plan 2023-25 outline the pathway to achieving the Government's commitment to ending gender-based violence in one generation through delivery of priority actions across the domains of prevention, early intervention, response, and recovery and healing. You can find out more about the National Plan and the related documents at: www.dss.gov.au/ending-violence.

The Government is taking a multi-pronged approach to end gender-based violence. Over the past 3 federal Budgets, the Government has committed more than $3.4 billion towards implementation of the National Plan. This commitment emphasises the need to hold perpetrators to account, reduce the re-occurrence of violence, and keep victim-survivors safe. The Government has invested in the following early intervention initiatives to stop violence escalating and prevent it re-occurring, such as:

$34.8 million for the Supporting Adolescent Boys Trial, a national early intervention trial for young men and adolescent boys who present with adverse childhood experiences including family and domestic violence, and who are at risk of using family, domestic or sexual violence.
$8.5 million for early intervention initiatives in relation to people using or at risk of using family, domestic and sexual violence.

$10.8 million to continue support to No to Violence to deliver the Men's Referral Service and Brief Intervention Service, which offer critical support to men who use family violence, their friends and family. It also delivers training to the sector that supports men to change their abusive and violent behaviour.

$27 million to partner with states to apply and trial innovative approaches to address perpetrators of family, domestic and sexual violence, and build the evidence-base for methods that work to change perpetrator behaviour.

In recognition of the need to accelerate efforts to end gender-based violence, the Prime Minister, the Hon Anthony Albanese MP convened a National Cabinet on 1 May 2024, bringing together First Ministers from all jurisdictions to discuss this critical issue and agree on priority areas for further action. National Cabinet agreed to strengthen prevention efforts through targeted, evidence-based approaches and to be informed by an expert-led rapid review of best practice approaches. First Ministers also agreed they would:
build on efforts currently underway, including strengthening accountability and consequences for perpetrators of family violence.
strengthen system responses, with a focus on high-risk perpetrators and serial offenders to prevent homicides.
improve information sharing about perpetrators across systems and jurisdictions, led by the Minister for Women, Senator the Hon Katy Gallagher.

On 23 August 2024, the Rapid Review Expert Panel released its final report containing 21 recommendations across 6 key areas for action by the Government, states and territories, and contained specific and practical advice to strengthen prevention approaches. For further information, please refer to www.pmc.gov.au/resources/unlocking-the-prevention-potential.

National Cabinet met for a second time on 6 September 2024 and agreed to a package of practical next steps, with the Government investing a further $4.4 billion to prevent violence and support legal services. The initiatives respond to key recommendations made in the Rapid Review Expert Panel final report. At this meeting, First Ministers agreed to deliver innovative new approaches to better identify high risk perpetrators, share information about them across systems and state boundaries, and intervene early to stop violence escalating. First Ministers agreed to:
Develop new national best practice family and domestic violence risk assessment principles and a model best practice risk assessment framework.

Support enhancements to the National Criminal Intelligence System, which enables information sharing across jurisdictions, to provide a 'warning flag' that will assist police responding to high-risk perpetrators.
Extend and increase nationally-consistent, two-way information sharing between the family law courts and the state and territory courts, child protection, policing and firearms agencies.

Strengthen system responses to high-risk perpetrators to prevent homicides, by trialling new focussed deterrence models and Domestic Violence Threat Assessment Centres. These centres will be able to use intelligence, monitor individuals and intervene with those at high risk of carrying out homicide.
I appreciate you bringing this matter to the Minister's attention. I trust the information provided will be of assistance to the Committee.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister for Prevention of Family Violence, Mrs Elliot
Migration
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 8 October 2024 enclosing Petition EN6443, with 109 signatures, concerning permanent visa pathways for temporary visa holders who have contributed to the Australian economy during the COVID-19 pandemic.

On 27 April 2023, the Government committed to provide a pathway to permanent residence for all temporary skilled visa holders. This has now occurred following a number of regulatory changes in November 2023. This pathway is in addition to existing pathways that help maintain Australia as a destination of choice for skilled migrants. The pathway also helps restore permanency at the heart of Australia's skilled migration system as all temporary skilled migrant workers will now have a clear pathway to permanent residency.

Graduate visas are available to former student visa holders. The visa provides full work rights and allows international students to gain work experience in Australia's labour market after finishing their studies. The Government is also strengthening the pathway from graduate visas to temporary skilled visas to give employers more certainty about a graduate's ongoing work rights and pathways to permanent residence.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN6443 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Burke
Human Rights: Hong Kong
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 8 October 2024 enclosing Petition EN6475, with 201 signatures, concerning support for Hong Kong civilians to gain protection in Australia. I appreciate the time you have taken to bring this matter to my attention.

Since the end of World War 11, Australia has successfully settled more than 970,000 refugees and others in humanitarian need, recognising the valuable contribution that refugees provide to Australian society, culture and prosperity.

The Government is committed to a Humanitarian Program that can respond to international humanitarian crises as they arise, and to provide appropriate support for the travel and resettlement of refugees and others requiring Australia's protection.

Each humanitarian crisis is different, and the Government responds according to the relevant needs at the time. To ensure Australia continues to play its part, the Government works closely with both the international and domestic community, particularly the United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR), as we deliver Australia's humanitarian intake.
Consistent with the approach adopted by the UNHCR, Australia prioritises those cohorts who have the greatest resettlement need. This will focus on people outside their home country who are:
Assessed as refugees by the UNHCR and referred to Australia for resettlement;
Applicants proposed by a close family member in Australia; and
Vulnerable cohorts within refugee populations, including women and children, ethnic minorities, LGBTQI+ and other identified minority groups.

Any person, including those from Hong Kong, who believe they meet the requirements for a humanitarian visa and wishes to seek Australia's assistance can make an application. All applications are assessed on an individual basis with applicants required to demonstrate their humanitarian need.

Visa grants are subject to rigorous assessment, including health, character and security checks, which are conducted before individuals are granted a visa. Further information on how to apply can be found on the Department of Home Affairs' website at: immi.homeaffairs.gov.au/what-we-do/refugee-and-humanitarian- program/about-the-program/resettle-in-australia.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN6475 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Burke
Medicare
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 9 October 2024 concerning petition number EN6485 requesting the addition of hypnotherapy services to the Medicare Benefits Schedule (MBS}.

The Australian Government is committed to the mental health system reform to improve access and equity in mental health care and recognises this involves considering a range of models of care, types oftreatment and a diverse and highly skilled workforce. To meet the needs of Australians at various life stages and in a range of settings, the Government recognises the importance of strengthening coordinated care, collaboration, and multidisciplinary ways of working. This includes ensuring people have access to the right mix of mental health initiatives and clinical and non-clinical services to address their mental and physical health needs whilst ensuring safety and quality of care.
Determining scope of clinical practice is the responsibility of the health service organisation where a practitioner practices and is informed by the profession.

The addition of a new therapy service on the MBS generally requires an assessment by the Medical Services Advisory Committee (MSAC). The MSAC appraises new services and provides advice to Government on whether they should be publicly funded based on comparative safety, clinical effectiveness, and cost effectiveness, using the best available evidence. Further information is available at www.msac.gov.au.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Health and Aged Care, Mr Butler
Migration
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 8 October 2024, enclosing Petition EN6494, with 66 signatures, concerning immigration and housing. I appreciate the time you have taken to bring this matter to my attention.

I take on the role as Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs with a deep sense of responsibility and resolve. Australia is a multicultural nation where its first priority should be how we can focus on inclusion and bringing people together.

Migration is a critical part of Australia's social and financial development as a nation. Immigration provides our businesses with the skills they need, stimulates demand for goods and services, and increases our economic output. I am committed to maintaining strong borders and delivering an orderly and compassionate immigration strategy that is tailored to the needs of the nation.

The Australian Government released the Migration Strategy (the Strategy) in December last year. A key objective of the Strategy is building stronger Australian communities by better planning the migration intake. This will better connect skilled migrants to Australia's skill needs, helping to reignite productivity growth, which will ensure rising living standards, business growth and better wages. Student visa reforms in the Strategy will restore integrity and quality to the system, and ensure international students are not being exploited.

The Strategy includes a number of measures to return Net Overseas Migration to pre-pandemic levels, allowing Government to manage migration levels while also ensuring the Migration Program is focused on getting the right skills in the right places.

In respect of impact on housing, around 60 percent of visas under the permanent Migration Program are granted to migrants already onshore and in the community, residing in established households at the time of visa grant. This minimises the permanent Migration Program's near-term impact on housing, infrastructure and services.

The Government is also working to address housing shortages through significant investment in the Homes for Australia Plan, which aims to build 1.2 million new homes from 1 July 2024. Further information can be found on the Treasury Department's website at: https://ministers.treasury.gov.au/ministers/julie-collins- 2022/media-releases/homes-australia-plan-delivering-more-homes-australians.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN6494 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Burke

subdebateinfo.title: National Redress Scheme for Institutional Child Sexual Abuse

p.span: National Redress Scheme for Institutional Child Sexual Abuse
Dear Chair

Thank you for your email dated 22 October 2024 to the Minister for Social Services, the Hon Amanda Rishworth MP, concerning Petition EN6498—Demand Transparency and Fairness in Institutional Abuse Redress (the petition). The Minister has asked me to respond to you on her behalf.

I note the petition makes several recommendations to improve the operation of the National Redress Scheme for Institutional Child Sexual Abuse (the Scheme). I have addressed the petition's specific recommendations as follows.
The Scheme was established in 2018 and is a joint response by the Australian Government, in partnership with each state and territory government, to the recommendations of the Royal

Commission into Institutional Responses to Child Sexual Abuse's (Royal Commission) Redress and Civil Litigation Report. This is because governments agreed with the Royal Commission's recommendation that "the best structure for providing redress is through a single national redress scheme established by the Government".

The Scheme is structured such that participating governments and non-government institutions may be held liable for abuse and required to pay redress. While the Scheme provides only one payment, it is designed to reflect the breadth of potential liability of these participating jurisdictions and institutions depending on a survivor's individual experience of abuse.

The Scheme provides funding to a free and independent legal service called knowmore Legal Services (knowmore) to provide free legal advice and practical assistance for survivors of child sexual abuse, including support to prepare and submit an application to the Scheme.

It is a person's choice whether they seek free legal support through knowmore or engage a private legal firm to assist with their redress application, noting that the fees for engaging a private legal firm will not be reimbursed or otherwise paid for by the Scheme.

The Scheme is aware of instances where the cost of private legal fees has been unreasonably high and were deducted directly from survivors' redress payments without the survivor's understanding. The Scheme is actively working with state and territory peak legal bodies to educate the broader legal community about the redress scheme in an attempt to dissuade such predatory practices from occurring.
For completeness, I advise that it is also open to a person to seek support through the redress application process from a Redress Support Services at www.nationalredress.gov.au/help- support.

The Scheme is aware of predatory practices within some sections of the legal community seeking to exploit and profit from victims of child sexual abuse. This includes claim farming, which involves an individual or organisation targeting a person and pressuring them to make a redress application. People or firms operating in this way benefit from the survivor submitting a claim through their service by charging commission or high legal fees for their assistance.

The Ministers' Redress Scheme Governance Board continues to monitor these and related issues, including engaging with the Australian Law Reform Commission on actions that can be taken to address these issues. Queensland has implemented legislation to curb claim farming in an effort to protect the community from these predatory practices. The Scheme understands other jurisdictions are contemplating similar legislation.

The Scheme provides payments of up to $150,000 maximum in recognition of abuse experienced. While this amount is less than the maximum $200,000 payment recommended by the Royal Commission, the average redress payment amount paid by the Scheme is approximately $90,000, which is more than $20,000 higher than the $66,000 average payment amount contemplated by the Royal Commission.
The Scheme has recently made a number of changes to support even greater access to redress for survivors. This includes:
removing the restriction on people applying from gaol;
the option of having a finalised application reassessed where a relevant institution subsequently joins the Scheme or a government agrees to be the Funder of Last Resort; and
allowing additional information with a review request and introducing a 'no worse off provision so reviewed offers are not reduced by a differing interpretation of the application.

Additionally, per recommendation 3.11 of the Second Anniversary Review, the Scheme has made changes to the Assessment Framework to combine the recognition of impact of sexual abuse payment with the recognition of sexual abuse payment. This means that all eligible applicants to the Scheme will receive the recognition of sexual abuse and recognition of impact of sexual abuse payment. These payments combined come to a minimum redress payment of $10,000 ensuring all redress outcomes will expressly recognise the impact of the abuse that a person experienced.

I recognise that the petition further requests that the Australian, state and territory governments launch an investigation into the aforementioned matters immediately. I advise the Scheme is already subject to parliamentary scrutiny in the form of the Joint Standing Committee on Implementation of the National Redress Scheme (Committee).

The Committee is currently conducting an inquiry into the Scheme which covers a wide range of issues, including some raised in this petition. I understand the Committee may be releasing its report shortly.

Further, in addition to the Second Year Review of the Scheme conducted by Ms Robyn Kruk AO in June 2021, there is a legislative requirement under section 192(3) of the National Redress Scheme for Institutional Child Sexual Abuse Act 2018, that the Minister responsible for the Scheme must cause a review into its operation to commence as soon as possible after the 8th anniversary of the Scheme's start day, being 1 July 2026. The 'eight-year review' of the Scheme will provide a further opportunity for review and comment into the operation of the Scheme.
In light of the current and future inquiries, the Minister will not be recommending that the Government pursue further investigations into the Scheme at this time.
I trust that this information is of assistance to you.
Yours sincerely
from the Assistant Minister for Social Services, Ms Elliott
Migration
Dear Chair
Thank you for your correspondence of 8 October 2024 enclosing Petition EN6544, with 185 signatures, concerning residency for farm workers who supported agriculture during COVID-19.

Migration is a critical part of Australia's social and financial development as a nation. Immigration provides our businesses, including the agriculture sector, with the skills they need, stimulates demand for goods and services and increases our economic output. I am committed to delivering an orderly and compassionate immigration strategy that is tailored to the needs of the nation.

Skilled migrants play an important role in nation building, cultural diversity and social cohesion, as well as contributing significant economic benefits. The Skilled visa programs are designed to ensure that overseas workers supplement but do not displace Australian workers. Australia's universal, non-discriminatory migration programs are designed to support a safe, prosperous and united Australia.

You may be aware that on 11 December 2023 the Government released the Migration Strategy, which was developed to deliver a better managed and more targeted migration system. On 25 November 2023, as part of these reforms, the Government provided a simpler and clearer pathway to permanent residence for all Temporary Skill Shortage (TSS) visa holders, including:
removing the limit on the number of Short-term TSS applications visa holders can make in Australia.
expanding eligibility for the permanent employer sponsored visas to holders of all TSS visa streams.

removing the requirement for nominated occupations for permanent employer sponsored visas in the Temporary Residence Transition (TRT) stream to be assessed against a skilled migration occupation list.
reducing the work experience requirement for the TRT stream to two years instead of three years.

I encourage the farm workers and farmers referred to in this petition to seek advice on the potential visa pathways available to them. They may wish to refer to the Department of Home Affairs website for information on visa options, or alternatively, may wish to seek the advice of a registered migration agent.
Thank you for bringing Petition EN6544 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Burke
Refugees Banking and Financial Services
Dear Chair

Thank you for your correspondence of 12 September 2024 enclosing Petition PN0613, with 706 signatures, concerning the resettlement of refugees from Indonesia. I appreciate the time you have taken to bring this matter to my attention.

Australia has a long history of providing resettlement for refugees and others who are displaced as a result of conflict, persecution and human rights abuses. Since the end of World War II, Australia has successfully settled more than 950,000 refugees and others in humanitarian needs.

The Australian Government is committed to compassionate and flexible Humanitarian and Settlement Programs that meet Australia's international protection obligations, and position Australia as a global leader in international resettlement efforts. The Government has allocated 20,000 places in Australia's 2024-25 Humanitarian Program, and is committed to delivering these places in full.

Our generous Humanitarian Program continues to provide lawful pathways to Australia to refugees and others in humanitarian need, which helps to stabilise refugee populations, reduces the prospect of irregular movement from source countries and countries of first asylum, and supports broader international protection objectives.

I acknowledge the world is currently experiencing the greatest level of humanitarian need in history, and as the Minister for Immigration, I am mindful to ensure our Humanitarian Program continues to respond to crisis around the world as they arise. The Australian Government has established policy to guide decisions on which applications are given priority. More detail on the Humanitarian Program can be found at https://immi.homeaffairs.gov.au/what-we-do/refugee-and-humanitarian-program/about- the-program/about-the-program and humanitarian program (homeaffairs.gov.au).

This petition raises concerns regarding the cohort of refugees in Indonesia. In addition to the Humanitarian and Settlement Program, Australia is committed to working with Indonesia to manage irregular migration in Indonesia, including through a Regional Cooperation Agreement (RCA). The RCA, which is administered by the International Organization for Migration, supports the Government of Indonesia's management of refugees and asylum seekers population across Indonesia. The RCA assists approximately 5,500 refugees and asylum seekers who registered with United Nations High Commissioner for Refugees (UNHCR) in Indonesia before 31 March 2018, while they await resettlement outcomes through the UNHCR.

Our Government is also committed to maintaining strong and secure borders. By maintaining strong borders, we can deliver an orderly and compassionate immigration system that is tailored to the needs of the nation.

Under Operation Sovereign Borders (OSB), anyone who attempts an unauthorised maritime voyage will be turned back to their point of departure, returned to their home country, or a country to which they have a right of entry, or transferred to regional processing. Anyone who attempts to travel to Australia by boat without a valid visa will be denied entry and settlement in Australia.
Thank you for bringing Petition PN0613 to my attention.
Yours sincerely
from the from the Minister for Immigration and Multicultural Affairs, Mr Burke
PETITIONS
Statements

Ms TEMPLEMAN
( Macquarie ) ( 10:01 ):
There are only paper petitions for presentation today, as no electronic petitions have closed for signature since last week's report. One of these petitions relates to child labour in the chocolate supply chain. Another relates to Falun Gong practitioners in China, and the third relates to Australia's greenhouse gas emission reduction targets and has more than 2½ thousand signatures. The principal petitioner, Dylan McCarthy, is a high school student from Wentworth Falls in my electorate of Macquarie. I met with Dylan before this sitting fortnight to receive the petition he's been gathering signatures for all year as part of a school project. It's been the result of many hours, and days, of work to disseminate the petition and gather signatures. Like so many young Blue Mountains residents, he's backing strong action on climate change, and I'm very pleased to be presenting this petition.

With the rise and convenience of electronic petitioning, it's not surprising that paper petitions now make up a small minority of petitions to this House. Nevertheless, they provide a unique quality. The paper often bears physical marks of the act of grassroots petitioning. Some pages may be well-worn after passing through numerous hands or after being attached to a clipboard. There are often many ink types on a page, and, of course, there is a multitude of handwriting styles. Some petitions appear to have been created by, or signed by, children. This is completely legitimate, as there is no age limit to petition this House. The paper petition remains a tangible and important element of our petitioning system.

Being the last sitting week scheduled for 2024, I thank my fellow committee members for their work considering petitions and facilitating the petitions process. I also thank ministers for the responses provided to petitions during the year. And, of course, I thank the secretariat, who assists us so ably in our work. After this week, the committee will look forward to 2025, when we will consider further petitions and responses that will have come in over the break in sittings.
BILLS
Doctors for the Bush Bill 2024
First Reading
Bill and explanatory memorandum presented by Mr Gee.
Bill read a first time.
Second Reading
Mr GEE (Calare) (10:04): I move:
That this bill be now read a second time.
Today I rise to introduce the Doctors for the Bush Bill 2024.
The rural doctor shortage is at crisis point.
It's a health disaster unfolding before our eyes, and its consequences are devastating.
All over central western New South Wales and around country Australia, doctors are leaving the bush and they're not being replaced.
In the electorate of Calare, the rural doctor shortage crisis is being felt in communities big and small.
Gulgong had four doctors but no longer has any at all.
This is putting pressure on the larger towns like Mudgee. It has two medical practices, and they are both no longer accepting any new patients.

Practices in communities like Canowindra and Molong have also lost doctors and are also closing their books to new patients or adopting a locals-only policy for appointments. In Wellington, it takes two months to see a GP.
The impacts this crisis is having on the health of country people are as concerning as they are shocking.
I spoke to one doctor in our area recently who met with a patient with advanced cancer and who had not been able to get in to see a doctor and had therefore missed out on vital treatment.
The rural doctor shortage crisis has been made much worse because country areas no longer have priority for overseas trained doctors.

Before July 2022, if an overseas trained doctor, or international medical graduate as they're known, wanted to practice in Australia and bill Medicare, they had to work in a country area for up to 10 years. These country areas were known, and are still known, as Distribution Priority Areas.
Bonded medical students also have to complete return-of-service obligations in a distribution priority area.
For many rural areas, this policy was a lifeline, providing competent GPs where there were none and ensuring that country people had access to basic medical services.
But in July 2022 all of that changed.
The government upended the Distribution Priority Area system, for the first time allowing outer metropolitan areas to be classified as Distribution Priority Areas.
All parts of Australia are classified according to what is called the Modified Monash Model. There are seven categories, ranging from MM1, which is a major city, to MM7, which is very remote.

Previously areas MM3 to MM7 were classified as Distribution Priority Areas. To give people context, larger regional centres like Bathurst and Orange are classified as MM3, Lithgow and Mudgee are MM4 and Molong, Gulgong and Canowindra are MM5.
The government has declared MM2 areas as Distribution Priority Areas now, thereby destroying—
Mr Katter: It's exactly the same in Queensland.

Mr GEE: I take the member for Kennedy's important interjection. It's the same in Queensland. What has happened is it has destroyed the priority area for overseas trained doctors that country areas once had; they have lost their priority for these doctors.

This has meant that areas such as Fairfield, Hornsby, Warringah and the outer suburbs of Sydney and Melbourne now have the same priority as country areas for overseas trained doctors as country areas.
When you look at the map, the whole state of New South Wales is now basically one big Distribution Priority Area except for the inner suburbs of Sydney.
How could this possibly be? Sydney does not have a doctor shortage.

The Doctors for the Bush Bill 2024 remedies this blatant unfairness by restoring the priority that country areas should have by legislating that Modified Monash areas MM1 and MM2 can't be classified as Distribution Priority Areas.
It will mean that country areas once again have priority for international medical graduates.
This restores the Distribution Priority Area system to that which existed before the last federal election.
I would therefore expect that every single coalition MP will be lining up to support this bill.
This crisis isn't going away any time soon.
It's predicted Australia will be short 10,600 GPs by 2031.
At the same time, demand for GP services is expected to increase by 58 per cent over the next decade.
There is a fundamental unfairness and inequality in access to health services in this country.
In the central west of New South Wales, we call the Great Dividing Range the sandstone curtain. It divides city and country physically but in so many other ways as well.
There exists a stark divide in health outcomes between people who live in the cities and those who call the bush home. It's a divide as high as the Great Dividing Range itself.
In fact, the further away you live from a city, the sooner you are likely to die—and that's the cold hard truth.
Statistics from the Australian Institute of Health and Welfare reveal that, devastatingly, people who live in very remote areas die about 15 years earlier than their city cousins.

With close to one-third of the Australian population living in the regions, how can this possibly be? The answer is simple: country people have less access to doctors such as GPs, who are often the first point of contact when someone feels sick or has a health problem.

According to the Department of Health and Aged Care, in the six months following the changes to the Distribution Priority Areas in 2022, the number of GPs that moved away from country practice jumped by more than 55 per cent on previous years. These are the changes that the current government brought in.

Now the government will say that more overseas trained doctors are coming to Australia than ever before, and they're right. They are coming. But they're just not coming to country areas. We know this because our medical practices are at breaking point.
This just adds more pressure to already overstretched hospitals and their emergency departments.
Overseas trained doctors are choosing to practice in and around the major cities for many different reasons.

For starters they can earn more money. City people have higher incomes than country people it's as simple as that. Doctors can charge more. There is more support for GPs practising in the cities than there is in the country. Practices are larger in the cities. Workloads can be shared. Workloads can be easier and better managed. There's more peer support. Colleagues can be consulted about cases.

This is why I've requested that the health minister visit our region and see for himself this unfolding crisis. We don't want to berate or belittle him. We want to work with him to find solutions. And the Doctors for the Bush Bill is part of the cure.
My office is constantly receiving correspondence from constituents concerned about this issue. Kathleen Bruce writes about the GP and paediatrician shortage. She says:
My husband and I have always worked really hard, pay heaps of tax, is it not too much to ask for some health care for our children? It is Australia, it's a human right.
Jodie Lewis writes:
I love it here and don't want to move again but my partner will consider selling and moving if my daughter can't access a doctor when required.
Ian Marsh, the president of Gulgong RSL sub-branch, writes:

We are losing veterans from the community who after settling in our wonderful community post service have now found that they are not able to be supported through their post service lives by our Health system … I have grave fear for an adverse outcome as veterans are forced to battle alone due to the paucity of services.
The government needs to get serious about alleviating the rural doctor shortage.

Together in this House and the other place, we have the power to cure this crisis. Country people demand and deserve nothing less than equality in access to doctors and medical services. Lives are at stake, and immediate action from this parliament is required.
I urge all members of this House to support the Doctors for the Bush Bill 2024 and achieve better health outcomes for country people.
I commend the Doctors for the Bush Bill to the House and cede the rest of my time to the member for Kennedy.
The SPEAKER: Is the motion seconded?

Mr KATTER (Kennedy) (10:12): I take great pleasure in seconding the motion. It is a great honour to be able to second this resolution. I do not hope to do justice to it as much as did the previous speaker. It was one of the better addresses that I've heard in this parliament.

Having said that, I will say that for seven years of my life I carried around in my briefcase that I take everywhere with me the names of six overseas doctors because, as the member of parliament for Queensland's mid-west, I was determined that Julia Creek would always have a doctor. Before I went into parliament it never had a doctor. In theory it was supposed to have one, but the doctor never made it there. Then they brought in another doctor to go there. He'd agreed to go, but then he wouldn't. So I carried around the names of these overseas doctors that I could ring up who would come over to Australia and take up the position if it was offered to them.

What overcame that problem was one of the great ladies of Australian history, Lady Pearl Logan, who gave us equal educational opportunities in country areas. But she was also chairman of the body—my daughter, who was secretary of the body, got all the praise, and I think Professor Ian Ronski was the real driver—that got the first medical school built in Australia in 44 years. That dramatically overcame the problem, because 18 universities then walked through the door that we were able to open. The sandstone universities didn't want any competition. They wouldn't expand, so for about 20 years we just sat there with the same number of doctors coming out. But now there are 18 universities. I listened in horror to my colleague from Orange giving those figures. Why hasn't it solved the problem? When they get through now, in a study that I've seen, they feel that they should take it easy or get a government job, which will be more highly paid than any other. (Time expired)
The SPEAKER: The time allocated for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned, and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting.

subdebateinfo.title: Online Safety Amendment (Digital Duty of Care) Bill 2024

p.span: Online Safety Amendment (Digital Duty of Care) Bill 2024
First Reading
Bill and explanatory memorandum presented by Ms Daniel.
Bill read a first time.
Second Reading
Ms DANIEL (Goldstein) (10:16): I move:
That this bill be now read a second time.
Research from the Foundation for Social Health shows that the emergence of social media correlates with young Australians now being the loneliest cohort in our society.
Previously, it was the over 60s who topped the stats on social isolation, but now it's apparently our most connected generation that feels most disconnected.

Ninety-one per cent of participants in the millennial and gen Z generational cohorts reported that social media has taken away from their real-life interaction with friends, family and community in some way.

Human society has long had a dual relationship with technology. New inventions—particularly those with the potential for transformational change—have carried an inherent but invisible framework of risk and reward.

And since the emergence of social media, we have failed to manage that risk. Now, we're faced with the challenge of retrofitting rules onto enormously powerful societal influencers—the companies that run these platforms.

And I would argue that we should do that not with bandaid measures but with an approach that manages the whole environment where the harm is taking place—and puts the responsibility on the platforms not the users.

Over the last decade or two, as social media and big tech have entrenched their practices and business models, governments—like the former coalition government—have designed 'content' based take-down regulatory models like those previously designed for broadcast media.
It makes sense—broadcast something that doesn't meet community standards—remove it or don't do it again.
But of course those legacy media environments didn't have the algorithm to spread content like wildfire the way information moves on social media now.
In lieu of a better idea, it's understandable that governments returned to what used to work.
And when the former government enacted the Online Safety Act, it was world leading in its ability to combat the spread of harmful content. There was, to put it bluntly, no better idea.
But now there is.

The Online Safety Amendment (Digital Duty of Care) Bill, like the European Digital Services Act and UK's Online Safety Act, is modelled off of the groundbreaking work of Professor Lorna Woods and a four-year project from Carnegie UK Trust.
Core to this model, now implemented in the EU and UK, are five interoperating key elements.
And the core aim—to make the platforms make their spaces safe for us, for our kids, for our communities.
First, the bill implements a singular and overarching statutory duty of care required by digital platforms for the wellbeing of their Australian users.

A duty of care is not only just but essential. It is appropriately broad in scope to ensure that all of the systems, processes and elements of a digital service are captured, including 'dark patterns' and addictive design features.
Now I've been talking about this for some time, and I acknowledge that the government is gradually signalling its intent to move in this direction eventually.
But a duty of care isn't enough on its own. It must be given teeth.
Second and third therefore, the bill frames a complementary scheme of risk assessments and risk mitigation.

Platforms will be regularly required to assess for the risk that their algorithms and other digital systems could have on mental health, the rights of the child, gender based violence and electoral processes, for example.

Platforms will also be required to prepare an accompanying mitigation plan which demonstrates to the government and the people exactly how they will reprogram or change their algorithms and systems to prevent these risks in the first instance.
This is how we make social media safe by design.

Without pressuring digital platforms to make all of their algorithms and systems progressively safer over time, governments around the world will continue to resort to handbrake measures, such as age based prohibition.

Age gating will not make platforms safer. It will maintain the situation where safety is the responsibility of the user—including parents and children—and indeed it may have the unintended consequence of further socially isolating some young people.
Far better, surely, than attempting to lock young people out (without even knowing if or how that can work), to make the space safe.
Fourth, and critically, the bill imposes mandatory transparency measures to ensure the government and public understand and can monitor how algorithmic systems are functioning.

This involves mandatory data access for public-interest research, and regular transparency reporting on key metrics, such as usage statistics and quantitative data on exposure of children to harmful content.

Fifth, this regime must be backed up with enforceability. Digital platforms under this bill will be liable for civil penalties of up to 10 per cent of annual turnover for noncompliance, and their senior management with penalties consistent with securities fraud.
And the bill will require platforms to enable people to reset and switch off the algorithm if they so choose and require the strongest privacy settings by default.
I acknowledge the work of my expert and lived experience Eating Disorders Working Group, which in many ways has been the starting point for my work in this space.
There is no silver bullet for online safety. But this five-element regulatory framework is demonstrably effective, and has become the international best practice.

I commend this bill to the House—because Australia can once again become a world leader in online safety. In the words of Professor Lorna Woods, 'We need a response that is preventative, not palliative.'
Humans designed these systems. And so, where we must, we can redesign them to serve our collective needs, rather than those of Mr Zuckerberg and Mr Musk.
This groundswell here has already begun.

The Foundation for Alcohol Research and Education, the Foundation for Social Health, the Human Rights Law Centre, Reset Tech Australia, AWO Agency, Queensland University of Technology, the Butterfly Foundation and the Black Dog Institute have all joined me in Canberra in recent weeks backing the changes that would occur under this bill.
I urge the government to allow debate and adopt this legislation, and I cede the rest of my time to the member for Kooyong.
The SPEAKER: Is the motion seconded?

Dr RYAN (Kooyong) (10:19): I second the motion. Social media has transformed how humans spend their time and how we communicate. The online world is, for many young people, a preferred place to access information, to build social and technical skills, to connect with our families and friends, to learn about the world, to relax and to play. These opportunities are really important in the transition to adulthood, but social media has well documented and significant risks for children and young people. These risks do need to be addressed by government.

In recent months both major political parties in Australia have rushed to ban social media access for young people. Their proposals are broad in scope but short on detail. They abdicate all responsibility to digital providers. They are not evidence based, they risk being utterly ineffectual and they risk potentially significant unintended consequences. The UN Committee on the Rights of the Child states:
National policies should be aimed at providing children with the opportunity to benefit from engaging with the digital environment and ensuring their safe access to it.

Whether bans are practically possible remains debatable. There are significant concerns regarding privacy, data and consent. Bans could well create more risk for children who still use platforms, because they will remove the incentives to ensure robust child safety features for those younger users who evade age assurance measures. Bans will not improve those products which children will still be allowed to use.

What is the problem here? The fact that we in this country allow billion-dollar companies to market unsafe digital products, or the fact that some of the people who use those products are teenagers? Experts have suggested that we should look at more targeted interventions rather than rushing to poorly considered, technically challenging blanket bans on social media access. Systemic regulation can drive up safety and privacy standards on all platforms for all children, and this approach has been supported by expert groups in mental health, digital literacy and child psychology.

For that reason, I am happy to support the member for Goldstein's proposal to amend the Online Safety Act to impose an overarching standard of care for large providers. This will mandate risk assessments and risk mitigation plans, mandatory transparency and reporting, and stringent enforcement mechanisms. It will protect our children. Something worth doing is worth doing well, in an evidence-balanced way. If the government accepts this bill today, we will start protecting young children immediately. I commend it to the House.
The SPEAKER: The time allotted for this debate has expired. The debate is adjourned, and the resumption of the debate will be made an order of the day for the next sitting.
PRIVATE MEMBERS' BUSINESS
Workforce Shortages
Mr VAN MANEN (Forde—Chief Opposition Whip) (10:26): I move:
That this House:
(1) notes that:
(a) reform is required to retain workers in the building and construction industry; and

(b) Master Builders Australia has reported that there is a critical workforce shortage, with a 14.7 per cent decrease in the number of construction industry apprentices completing their studies since 2022, and the total number of construction apprentices also decreasing by 22.4 per cent for the same period; and
(2) acknowledges that the:
(a) Government has delivered a business insolvency crisis, with over 23,938 business insolvencies since taking office, including over 6,399 construction business insolvencies;
(b) Government's Fee Free TAFE program has delivered a 13 per cent completion rate to date and the Government has refused to reveal the dropout rate;
(c) Government is failing Australian businesses and the construction sector; and
